title: Warlord's turned into mastery that interacts with crit chance and movement
body: When Yasuo breaks it _again_, can we officially rename it to Weeblord's Bloodlust?

replies.body: Can we just get rid of keystones?

Honestly, I may be in the minority with this opinion, but I like the idea of the keystones. They give the idea of player freedom with talent builds and can lead to interesting play styles. The problem is that the current talent trees are to cookie cutter. Everyone picks the same thing for the same champion and have to use whatever the dominant key stone is for that champion or not be able to play the champion to its full potential and get trolled by team mates. 

The talent trees themselves need to be reworked all over again, honestly the old talent trees offered more diversity than the current ones and you could get away with different builds easier back then, they weren't that different and cookie cutters were dominant back then too. This is the issue with tying so many modifiers into the trees. All they did when they changed the old trees into the current was cut down the number of options and added the key stones. Less options doesn't exactly lead to diversity, when the majority of the talents are still dmg/def modifiers.

I like the idea of key stones because they encourage developing different play styles depending on how you want to build the champion but again the current trees and even the current Key Stones, which are just bigger dmg/def modifiers than the rest of the talents, don't encourage this idea at all. This is also the same for most item builds. Diversity just loses to the strongest cookie cutter. Making talents more unique and less numbery would be a step in the right direction I think, and can lead to better key stones. But this is my opinion, figured I put it out there. The new Warlords definetly is a step in the right direction though.

The problem is, IMO, that keystones as a whole presented a whole lot of extra power that wasn't in the old mastery system, especially offensively.  Thunderlords and DFT and Fervor provide a ton of extra damage that you couldn't get with the old masteries, and the game's base statistics were not updated to match.

I think that the keystones were a good idea overall.  I think that we should have seen an update to the game itself to compensate for the greater power coming in for every champion, though.

How is Warlord's still in the game when they took out Strength for being "stale"?  Healing with auto attacks is actually a toxic mechanic, and as long as it involves healing and autos, it will be impossible to balance.

Strength was picked by literally every jungler, because it was the only PVE keystone. 

This became problematic because champions that aren't supposed to be getting tanky were getting tanky without investing any gold into it. Champions like Lee Sin, Amumu and Nautilus will find 300 health useful and largely redundant. Champions like Nidalee, Graves and Evelynn can pull off plays they simply shouldn't be able to with 300 extra health as long as they aren't diverting from their full damage build to get it. 

Warlord's was picked by every carry, which actually was a problem less so because of the healing and moreso because then ADCs weren't dealing enough damage in team fights without lethality because crit and AS items were nerfed to fit the old on-hit Fervor and then on-hit Fervor was ruined. 

Basically Warlords has to be gimped enough that it doesn't matter in lane, so champions aren't forced to pick it to survive laning phase. Then they aren't shooting rubber bullets in team fights later.

All in all, crit just needs to get its damage back and Riot needs to either let Fervor die or accept that adding so much base damage to the game is going to cause issue when you aren't nerfing the champions themselves to compensate.
Which is why they're changing it to a periodic punctual healing
